prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would. An aquarium has a rectangular base that measures 100 cm by 40 cm and has a height of 50 cm. The aquarium is filled with water to a depth of 37 cm. A rock with volume $1000 \text{cm}^3$ is then placed in the aquarium and completely submerged. By how many centimeters does the water level rise?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest 100th.
gpt_response:
To solve this problem, we can use the principle of fluid displacement. When the rock is placed in the aquarium, it displaces a volume of water equal to its own volume. Therefore, the amount by which the water level rises will be equal to the volume of the rock divided by the surface area of the base of the aquarium.

The volume of the rock is given as $1000 \text{cm}^3$. The surface area of the base of the aquarium is $100 \text{cm} \times 40 \text{cm} = 4000 \text{cm}^2$.

Therefore, the amount by which the water level rises is calculated as:

$\text{Rise in water level} = \dfrac{1000 \text{cm}^3}{4000 \text{cm}^2} = 0.25 \text{ cm}$

So, the water level rises by 0.25 cm when the rock is placed in the aquarium.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 0.25\,\text{ cm}?: To solve this problem, we can use the principle of fluid displacement. When the rock is placed in the aquarium, it displaces a volume of water equal to its own volume. Therefore, the amount by which the water level rises will be equal to the volume of the rock divided by the surface area of the base of the aquarium.

The volume of the rock is given as $1000 \text{cm}^3$. The surface area of the base of the aquarium is $100 \text{cm} \times 40 \text{cm} = 4000 \text{cm}^2$.

Therefore, the amount by which the water level rises is calculated as:

$\text{Rise in water level} = \dfrac{1000 \text{cm}^3}{4000 \text{cm}^2} = 0.25 \text{ cm}$

So, the water level rises by 0.25 cm when the rock is placed in the aquarium.
